description.en:
"Development of new drug to treat infectious diseases and other conditions is currently facing both unprecedented opportunities and challenges; the later having more significant effect. Few drug reaching market, increasing prices of novel drug has generated negative image of pharmaceutical industry that has far reaching consequence. It is crucial that students in Bioengineering curriculum have objective understanding of the technologies and challenges in drug development. 

Part of course dedicated to principles of drug development will provide overview of drug development process and its different stages. Main goals and challenges associated with each of stage will be highlighted. Special cases (such as orphan drug development) will be analyzed, Students are expected to analyze "real life" situation in drug development by analyzing of pipelines of pharmaceutical companies. Practical training includes hands-on "

objectives.en: The aim of the  course is to  show, using practical examples, principles of modern drug design and development. This is essential for general understanding of complexity of the process, critical stages of development process and main hurdles that limit efficiency of novel drug development

learning_outcomes.en: Students have theoretical understanding and practical experience about different approaches of drug design and early (discovery and preclinical) stages of drug development

independent_work.et:
1. Preparation of report on practical excesises
2. Work with materials (26) in preparation for examination

grade_preconditions.et:
All practical excesises are performed, corresponding reports are presented, presentation is prepared and presented. Alternatively, an essay is required for each missed practical excesize and/or oral presentation at least one week before examination. 
NB! Practical part of the course (lectures 11-16) will be carried out in research laboratories; therefor following laboratory rules (including safety) is mandatory. Failure to follow the rules and/or damaging of ongoing research will be treated as academic misconduct and this will automatically disqualify student from the course with no right to take final examination.

grade_evaluation.et:
The practical works have to be passed and report presented.

Written test passed.

The report and test contribute equally to the final grade.

debt_elimination.et:
Practical excesises are mandatory. The missed excesises will not be repeated. Students need to prepare and deliver an essay on related topic (such as publication in Nature Review Drug Discovery) for each missed practical excesise at least one week before examination.
Examination: one repeated examination according Study Regulations.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

Lecture materials

description.et:
Lectures:
1. Introduction to drug development.
Why are new drugs needed? What is difference between approved drugs and natural (traditional) medicine, food supplements, pseudo-drugs etc? Where do the drugs come from? Steps of drug development.
2. Computer Aided Drug Design 1 (CADD) 
Representation of chemical structure In Silico. Chemical space of drug substances - chemical class view. Ligand databases useful in drug design. In Silico Ligand Based Design (LBD) QSAR, 3D QSAR. Pharmacophore modelling. Chemical space of drug substances - property (or structure) view - Lipinski RoF and analogs. Virtual screening of ligand libraries (In silico ADME/Tox profiling).
3. Computer Aided Drug Design 2 (CADD).
Protein databases useful in drug design. Structure based design (SBD):
* Molecular docking
* Protein active site information in virtual screening
Merge of everything - complex in silico drug design workflows. Advanced modelling for LBD:
* Quantum chemistry in drug design
* Hierarchical classification of ligand libraries -learning from chemical data
* In Silico combinatorial libraries of ligand candidates
Advanced modelling for SBD:
* Molecular mechanics in drug design
* Molecular dynamics in drug design
* Screening of unwanted side-effects in early drug design
Other Advanced modelling techniques:
* Artificial intelligence and machine learning in drug design
* Ligand and target molecular interaction networks.
4. Screening of libraries. 
5. Hit-to-lead development.
6. Development of Macromolecular Therapeutics.
Macromolecular drugs: peptides, proteins, nucleic acid-based drugs. The opportunities for medicine and challenges for development. Drug delivery systems.

7. Molecular mechanism of drug action. 
Do we need to know how drug candidate works? Drugs with known mechanism of action. Drugs with unknown mechanism of action. Re-purposing of drugs (second indication): why is needed and how to do? If drug fails can it still be used? Drugs, failed drugs and drug development process as source of new knowledge/tools in molecular biology.
8. Pre-clinical trials. 
Why are pre-clinical trials needed? Why we need in vivo experiments? How to choose model? How many trials must be performed and how many models must be used. Development of in vivo models as part of drug development process. What is "animal rule": when and how it can be used?
9. Clinical trials.
10. Commercial aspect of drug development. 
Main hurdles in drug development process. How to finance research that costs bullions (examples of buisness plans). Logic behind drug prices. Orphan drugs.

11. Practical (practical 1). 
In silico exercise Virtual screening of ligand libraries - using some standard ligand database.
12. Practical (practical 2-3). 
Toxicity of drug compound for mammalian cell. Anti-microbial effect of drug compounds. Delivery of nucleic acid based drug. Students are encouraged to select compound (or extract etc) of their choice and text its biological properties in cell-culture assays.
